__data__.text: FOOT & ANKLE INTERNATIONAL

Peroneus Brevis Tendon Tears: Pathophysiology, Surgical Reconstruction, and Clinical Results
John O. Krause, M.D.
: and James W. Brodsky, MD.t

Peroneus Brevis Tendon Tears: Pathophysiology, Surgical Reconstruction, and Clinical Results
Dallas, Texas

Peroneus Brevis Tendon Tears: Pathophysiology, Surgical Reconstruction, and Clinical Results > ABSTRACT
Chronic peroneus brevis tendon tears are frequently overlooked or misdiagnosed.
They are a more common problem than previously noted.
Twenty patients were reviewed in the largest clinical series of its kind.
The most reliable diagnostic sign was persistent swelling along the peroneal tendon sheath.
The pathophysiologic mechanism is subclinical, or overt, subluxation of the tendon over the posterolateral edge of the fibula.
This produces multiple longitudinal splits.
Treatment is pri­ marily surgical and must address both the split tendon and the subluxation that caused it.
A new classification that guides surgical treatment is proposed.
Debridement and repair are recommended for grade 1 tendons, which have damage to less than 50% of the cross-sectional area.
EXCisionof the damaged segment and tenodesis to the peroneus longus are recommended for grade 2 ten­ dons, which have destruction of greater than 50% of the cross-sectional area.
Both methods must be augmented by stabilization of the etiologic subluxation.
The average postoperative AOFAS score was 85.
Return to maximum function is prolonged, but good-to-excellent results were found in the majority of patients.

Peroneus Brevis Tendon Tears: Pathophysiology, Surgical Reconstruction, and Clinical Results > INTRODUCTION
Pain and swelling about the lateral or posterolateral side of the ankle represent difficult clinical problems.
Peroneus brevis tendon tears are an uncommonly re­ ported cause of lateral ankle pain and a frequently overlooked diagnosis.
Review of the literature reveals only 24 clinical cases of chronic peroneus brevis tears reported.
1,2,11,14,15,17,20,26,27 The largest series re- ported 11 patients with 12 affected tendons in a group of 47 patients undergoing surgical reconstruction of the lateral ankle liqarnents."?
Eight other patients were reported with swelling, popping, and retrofibular pain after successful nonoperative treatment of uncompli­ cated inversion ankle sprains.
Three of these had lon­ gitudinal splits in the peroneus brevis tendon at sur­ gical exploration."
Chronic peroneal tendon instability was reported in three patients who had longitudinal splits in the peroneus brevis in the retromalleolar sul­ cus.'
Anatomical studies have demonstrated the inci­ dence of peroneus brevis tears in cadaver specimens, a proposed mechanism of injury, and a relationship to lateral ankle instability.5,8, 13,21,23-25 In this paper we report a clinical study of 20 patients with chronic peroneus brevis tendon tears, including clinical presentation, surgical findings and techniques, results of treatment, and a proposed pathophysiolog­ ical mechanism of injury.

Peroneus Brevis Tendon Tears: Pathophysiology, Surgical Reconstruction, and Clinical Results > INTRODUCTION

Peroneus Brevis Tendon Tears: Pathophysiology, Surgical Reconstruction, and Clinical Results > MATERIALS AND METHODS
Twenty patients presented to the senior author (JWB) and eventually came to operative treatment for persistent pain and swelling over the posterolateral ankle over an 8-year period.
There were 10 male and 10 female patients with an average age of 44 years (range, 27-63 years).
Eleven patients reported a spe­ cific injury, whereas nine patients could not identify a precipitating traumatic event.
Four of the injuries were sports related (2 softball, 1 basketball, 1 racquetball), four were twisting injuries (3 inversion, 1 unknown), two were missteps with ankle dorsiflexion, and one was a fall on the floor.
One of the acutely injured patients had a history of chronic symptoms preceding the injury.
Thirteen of the 20 patients had been treated by at least one other physician before presentation to our office.
These 13 patients had multiple prior unsuc­ cessful treatments, including removable short leg walking orthoses in seven, physical therapy in six, corticosteroid injections in five, cast immobilization in two, polypropylene ankle-foot orthosis in one, and

Peroneus Brevis Tendon Tears: Pathophysiology, Surgical Reconstruction, and Clinical Results > MATERIALS AND METHODS
& Ankle Internationai/Vol.
19, No. 5/May 1998

Peroneus Brevis Tendon Tears: Pathophysiology, Surgical Reconstruction, and Clinical Results > MATERIALS AND METHODS
previous surgery in four.
The four previous surgeries (one each in each patient) were ankle arthroscopy/ synovectomy, sliding fibular osteotomy, superior per­ oneal retinaculum (SPR) reconstruction, and peroneal groove-deepening procedure with SPR reconstruc­ tion.
The average duration of symptoms prior to pre­ sentation at our office was 14 months (range, 0.5-36 months).
All patients except one (retired) were actively employed at the time of presentation, and seven cases were workman's compensation claims.

Peroneus Brevis Tendon Tears: Pathophysiology, Surgical Reconstruction, and Clinical Results > MATERIALS AND METHODS
Presentation

Peroneus Brevis Tendon Tears: Pathophysiology, Surgical Reconstruction, and Clinical Results > MATERIALS AND METHODS
All 20 patients presented with lateral ankle pain and tenderness.
In 18 patients, there was tenderness lo­ calized to the peroneal sheath and swelling over the peroneal tendons.
These 18 patients were all diag­ nosed preoperatively.
There were two patients in whom the diagnosis was made intraoperatively and not preoperatively.
In one of these two patients, the pain appeared to originate from the subtalar joint, and no peroneal swelling was noted.
The other patient had ankle instability and no noted peroneal swelling, and preoperative tenderness was localized to the lateral ankle ligaments.
Eight patients were noted to have readily dislocatable or subluxable tendons on preop­ erative exam.
Two patients were noted to have lateral ankle instability in addition to the anticipated peroneal tendon pathology at the time of surgery.
Three of the 20 patients had a varus hindfoot, one of whom had spasticity secondary to previously diagnosed gener­ alized dystonia.

Peroneus Brevis Tendon Tears: Pathophysiology, Surgical Reconstruction, and Clinical Results > MATERIALS AND METHODS > (5); T, peroneal tendons; R, inferior peroneal retinaculum; N, sural
nerve.
time of presentation to the authors, and two had fur­ ther nonsurgical treatment.

Peroneus Brevis Tendon Tears: Pathophysiology, Surgical Reconstruction, and Clinical Results > MATERIALS AND METHODS > (5); T, peroneal tendons; R, inferior peroneal retinaculum; N, sural
All patients had plane radiographs at the initial visit, and 15 patients had a preoperative MRI to evaluate the peroneal tendons.
Of the 15 MRls, 10 showed definite evidence of a peroneus brevis tear, four showed no definite tear, and one was equivocal be­ cause of postoperative changes from surgery done elsewhere.
There were significant numbers of false positives and false negatives, a not uncommon occur­ rence in MRI examination of tendons about the ankle."
Three of the five patients who did not have an MRI had readily dislocatable tendons, and MRI was judged to be unnecessary.
Of the other two other patients who did not have an MRI, neither was diagnosed as having peroneal tendon tear preoperatively but rather intra­ operatively.
Seven of the 20 patients sought initial treatment by the authors.
The nonsurgical treatments in this com­ bined group of (7) patients included short leg walking cast for 4 weeks in four patients, removable walking orthosis for 2 to 8 weeks in seven patients, intrasheath steroid injection in two, shoe insoles with lateral wedge in one, and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory medications in three patients.
Cast immobilization provided satisfactory relief of pain in two of the four patients, but pain recurred when the cast was changed to a removable walking orthosis.
No other nonoperative treatment provided significant relief of symptoms.

Peroneus Brevis Tendon Tears: Pathophysiology, Surgical Reconstruction, and Clinical Results > MATERIALS AND METHODS > Nonsurgical Treatment
Thirteen patients were treated nonoperatively by at least one other physician before presentation, at the average interval as noted above (14 months).
Eleven of the 13 had exhausted nonsurgical treatment by the A slightly curved 8- to 12-cm incision was made posterior to the lateral malleolus, following the course of the peroneal tendons.
The subcutaneous tissue was spread down to the peroneal sheath with care taken to identify and protect the sural nerve.
The sheath was inspected to look for redundancy or ele­ vation off the lateral surface of the fibula.
The tendons were then manipulated to assess any tendency to subluxate/dislocate.
Subluxation was present when the tendons could be manually displaced out of the groove, over the posterolateral fibular edge.
In pa­ tients with a functional peroneal sheath/retinaculum, manipulating the tendons will not cause the tendons to displace/subluxate around the posterolateral fibular edge.
The sheath was then opened longitudinally and the tendons inspected (Fig. 1).
A synovectomy was performed.
Nonviable and degenerated tendon in the area of the tear was resected.
The remaining tendon

Peroneus Brevis Tendon Tears: Pathophysiology, Surgical Reconstruction, and Clinical Results > MATERIALS AND METHODS > Nonsurgical Treatment
& Ankle International/Vol.
19, No. 5/May 1998

Peroneus Brevis Tendon Tears: Pathophysiology, Surgical Reconstruction, and Clinical Results > MATERIALS AND METHODS > Nonsurgical Treatment > Grade
1

Peroneus Brevis Tendon Tears: Pathophysiology, Surgical Reconstruction, and Clinical Results > MATERIALS AND METHODS > Nonsurgical Treatment > Grade
2 was graded as a guide to decide between repair of the tendon versus resection and tenodesis (see Table 1).
If 50% or more of the tendon was viable and remained after debridement of the damaged portion (grade 1), then the remaining, viable portion is repaired longitudinally with a running, 3-0 absorbable, braided (Vicryl~ suture, tubularizing the tendon to reestablish a smooth outer surface. If less than 50% of viable tendon was remaining after debridement of the dam­ aged portion of the tendon (grade 2), proximal and distal tenodeses of the brevis tendon to the longus tendon were performed with no. 1 absorbable, mono­ filament (PDS) suture.
Absorbable sutures were used to avoid persistent irritation within the tendon sheath.
To avoid fibula impingement, the proximal tenodesis was placed at least 3 to 4 em above, and the distal tenodesis at least 5 to 6 cm below, the tip of the lateral malleolus.
Reconstruction of the subluxation of the tendons was performed.
The tendons were retracted posteri­ orly, and the fibular groove was inspected (Fig. 2).
If the groove was shallow, flat, or convex, the groove was deepened.
This was done by incising the perios­ teum and preserving the periosteal flaps.
A small, curved gouge was used to deepen the posterior sur­ face of the fibula (Fig. 3), and the periosteal flaps were sutured back over the cancellous bone surface.
The SPR was repaired by advancing the posterior flap to

the fibula and securing it through a series of drill holes in the posterolateral margin of the fibula (Fig. 4).
The anterior flap of tendon sheath/SPR was then brought posteriorly and sutured to the posterior flap to rein­ force it.

Peroneus Brevis Tendon Tears: Pathophysiology, Surgical Reconstruction, and Clinical Results > MATERIALS AND METHODS > 273PERONEUS BREVIS TENDON TEARS > TABLE 1 Clinical Classification of Peroneus Brevis Tendon Tears > Treatment
The subcutaneous tissue and skin were closed in routine fashion, and plaster nonweightbearing (NWB) splints (posterior and stirrup splints) were applied in the operating room, over a bulky cotton modified Jones-type dressing.
Postoperative immobilization was 5 weeks NWB in a cast, followed by approxi­ mately 1 to 8 weeks of weightbearing immobilization in a combination of cast and removable walking brace.

was advanced to a removable walking brace.
Formal physical therapy was begun between 8 to 10 weeks postoperatively.

Peroneus Brevis Tendon Tears: Pathophysiology, Surgical Reconstruction, and Clinical Results > MATERIALS AND METHODS > Intemational/Vo/. 19, No. 5/May 1998
Evaluation Methods

Peroneus Brevis Tendon Tears: Pathophysiology, Surgical Reconstruction, and Clinical Results > MATERIALS AND METHODS > Intemational/Vo/. 19, No. 5/May 1998
Evaluation of the clinical results of treatment were done both subjectively and objectively.
Patients were interviewed and reexamined.
The results were evalu­ ated according to our own criteria, as well as with the AOFAS ankle/hindfoot score.'?
The presence or ab­ sence of a workman's compensation claim was noted for each patient.
Subjectively, patients were asked to evaluate their residual pain and its association with level of activity, limitations of activity, ability to return to work postop­ eratively, other treatments subsequent to surgery, level of subjective satisfaction, and subjective quanti­ fication of pain relief.
Objectively, the surgical findings were reviewed, and a grading system was developed (see Table 1).
Patients were examined for scar tender­ ness, residual deformity, alignment of the hindfoot and ankle, synovitis and swelling, ankle and hindfoot sta­ bility, gait abnormality, residual subluxation of the per­ oneal tendons, sensibility in the skin around the oper­ ative area, and range of motion of ankle and hindfoot.
Patients were also evaluated for ligamentous instabil­ ity radiographically using an instrumented joint stress device (Telos Stress Device®, Austin and Associates, Inc., Fallston, MD) to apply uniform stress of 15 kP for both inversion and anterior drawer stress testing of the ankle ligaments on both the affected and contralateral sides.

Peroneus Brevis Tendon Tears: Pathophysiology, Surgical Reconstruction, and Clinical Results > MATERIALS AND METHODS > Intemational/Vo/. 19, No. 5/May 1998
Fig. 5.
Intraoperative photograph of peroneus brevis tendon showing multiple, longitudinal full-thickness tears.

Peroneus Brevis Tendon Tears: Pathophysiology, Surgical Reconstruction, and Clinical Results > MATERIALS AND METHODS > RESULTS Surgical Findings
All of the 20 patients had multiple, longitudinal tears, splits, and fraying of the peroneus brevis tendon (Fig. 5).
In all patients, the tears were centered at the tip of the lateral malleolus, extending 1 to 2 cm proximally and/or distally.
In three patients, the tears extended more than 2 cm below the malleolus.
In two of these three, the longitudinal rents in the tendon extended to within 2 cm of the insertion at the base of the fifth metatarsal.
The tears were complex and multiple in all patients.
The typical pattern was of several parallel, partial, and/or full thickness longitudinal splits.
Splay­ ing of the tendon was a finding of advanced tendon destruction.
It occurred when there were extensive parallel splits, either partial or full thickness across the entire width of the tendon.
The multiple splits dis­ rupted the internal architecture of the tendon, render­ ing it flat rather than tubular in shape.
Nineteen of the 20 patients (95%) had demonstrable peroneal subluxation intraoperatively.
The one patient who did not was one of the two patients in whom the peroneal tendon tears were not diagnosed preopera­ tively.
In this patient, the tendon tear was found at the time of subtalar arthrodesis for degenerative arthritis and the sheath was opened before examining for this finding.
All 20 patients underwent SPR repair and im­ brication through fibular drill holes.
Eight patients had a deficient peroneal groove and underwent a groove deepening procedure as well.
Two of these eight ad­ ditionally had the peroneal tendons rerouted under the calcaneofibular ligament (CFL) by division and resu­ ture of the ligament.

Peroneus Brevis Tendon Tears: Pathophysiology, Surgical Reconstruction, and Clinical Results > MATERIALS AND METHODS > RESULTS Surgical Findings
A grading scale of severity of the tendon tears was developed based on the surgical findings (see Table 1).
This grading system is based on the cross-sec­ tional area of the tendon which is torn and irreparable.
Grades 1 and 2 are based on the percentage of ten­ don destruction.
According to this classification, grade 1 lesions were treated with repair of the pero­ neus brevis tendon after debridement, whereas grade 2 lesions were treated with tenodesis and resection of the damaged segment of the tendon.
The 11 patients (55%) with grade 1 tears underwent tendon debride­ ment and repair by tubularization, whereas the nine

Patient Data
64-86%) ination at the time of this retrospective review, 10 continued to have tenderness to palpation posterior to the lateral malleolus, whereas six had persistent swell­ ing in the peroneal sheath (5 mild, 1 moderate).
No patient had subluxable peroneal tendons on exam at follow-up.
One patient had a 1+ anterior drawer on instability testing.

Patient Data
Telos instrumented varus and anterior stress radio­ graphs were performed with 15 kP of force on 15 patients.
Fourteen were negative for both varus tilt and anterior translation.
One patient had 5 mm of anterior translation, which was bilaterally symmetric.

Patient Data
Nine patients had full, bilaterally symmetric range of motion (ROM) of the ankle and subtalar joints at fol­ low-up.
Six had full ankle ROM, but some limitation of subtalar motion, averaging 62% of the contralateral patients (45%) with two tears underwent tenodesis of the peroneus brevis to the peroneus longus tendon and excision of the damaged section of the peroneus brevis tendon (Table 2).
Other procedures were per­ formed as indicated and included: lateral ligament repair in three patients, subtalar arthrodesis in one patient, and tarsal tunnel release in one patient.

Patient Data > Clinical Results
The patients were followed for an average of 39 months (range, 14-84 months).
Two of the 20 patients moved out of state, and the most recent follow-up was by telephone questionnaire.
Fifteen patients were sat­ isfied with the surgery without reservations, four were satisfied with reservations, and one was dissatisfied.
The patients reported an average of 79% (range, 0-100%) of the preoperative pain was relieved by the surgery.
At follow-up, seven patients reported no pain, nine reported pain only with selected activities, and four reported pain at rest after activities of daily living (ADL).
Of the nine with pain associated with activities, one had moderate pain walking greater than 4 to 6 blocks, three had mild pain after walking greater than 1.5 miles, and five had mild to moderate pain only with running sports.
Among the 10 female patients, all of whom reported satisfaction with surgery, inability to wear high heels was the most common complaint.
Objectively, in the 18 patients available for reexam-

Three patients had 75% (range 64-86%) of nor­ mal contralateral ankle motion and an average of 60% of normal subtalar motion.
The remaining patient had a successful subtalar arthrodesis (Table 3).
The aver­ age AOFAS ankle/hindfoot score for the 20 patients was 85, with a range from 54 to 100 (Table 4).
one changed to a job requiring less walking, and one was retired preinjury.
Average AOFAS ankle/hindfoot score in this group was 92, with a range of 58 to 100.
Functional results in the workman's compensation group were good, but not at the same level as the nonworkman's compensation group.
One patient of the workman's compensation group reported no pain and participated in unlimited recreational activities, three had pain with selected activities, and three had pain at rest after ADL.
Six patients required intermit­ tent oral, nonnarcotic medications, and five periodi­ cally required a lightweight, soft ankle support.
Four (57%) returned to the same employment, two changed to more sedentary jobs, and one was unable to work because of combined disability from peroneal ten­ dons, a back injury, and a hand injury.
Average AOFAS ankle/hindfoot score for this group was 73, with a range from 54 to 90.
Tendon Repair versus Tenodesis Eleven patients underwent tendon repair, whereas nine had a debridement and tenodesis.
Nine of the 11 (82%) patients undergoing tendon repair were satis­ fied without reservations, one was satisfied with res­ ervations (9%), and one was dissatisfied (9%).
This compares with 67%, 33%, and 0%, respectively, for patients undergoing tenodesis.
The remaining results, both subjective and objective, were not substantially different between the two groups (see Table 6).

Patient Data > InternationallVol. 19, No. 5/May 1998 > Functional Results
Functional results were much better in the group of 13 non-workman's compensation (NWC) patients, compared to the workman's compensation (WC) pa­ tients (Table 5).
Seven patients in the workman's com­ pensation group participated in unlimited recreational activities.
Eight patients required no continuing treat­ ment, and five periodically used a lightweight, soft ankle support, and/or oral, nonnarcotic medications.
Eleven patients returned to the same employment,

Patient Data > InternationallVol. 19, No. 5/May 1998 > Functional Results > Complications
All wounds healed primarily without complication.
No patient had a unilateral foot deformity at follow-up.
Seven patients had minor paresthesias or decreased sensibility distal to the incision in the sural nerve dis­ tribution.
Four patients had tenderness over the scar and two patients had a positive percussion sign over the sural nerve.

Patient Data > InternationallVol. 19, No. 5/May 1998 > Functional Results > Complications > DISCUSSION
There is an increased awareness of the diagnosis of peroneus brevis tears and somewhat expanded atten­ tion in the literature in the last 8 years.2,3,5,8,11,19-27 There is a striking paucity of clinical information on diagnosis, recommended treatment techniques, and the results of treatment.
Like the original report by Meyer,13 the majority of recent publications on this entity have been done on cadaver speci­ mens.5,7,8,21-25

Patient Data > InternationallVol. 19, No. 5/May 1998 > Functional Results > Pathophysiologic Mechanism
Several authors have noted the critical role of sub­ luxation of the tendons over the posterolateral edge of

the fibula in the development of these tendon tears.
':11,13,14 This hypothesis for this pathophysio­ logic mechanism (of chronic subluxation) is reinforced by the observation that primarily chronically dislocat­ ing tendons have been demonstrated to develop these tears.
The surgical findings in our patients con­ firm the previous authors clinical and laboratory ob­ servations regarding the location of the tears, their longitudinal nature, and the key role of subluxation over the posterior corner of the lateral malleolus.6,13,23 Despite the fact that 19 of our 20 patients had subluxation intraoperatively, only eight patients had preoperative clinically subluxating tendons.
The mechanism for acute peroneal tendon dislocation had been described as strong eversion of a dorsiflexed foot by previous authors.
':" However, the mechanism for pathologic changes of the peroneal retinaculum causing subtle peroneal tendon subluxation is not clearly the same and is still somewhat uncertain when comparing our findings with the anatomic studies in the recent literature.

Patient Data > InternationallVol. 19, No. 5/May 1998 > Functional Results > Pathophysiologic Mechanism > Repair Tenodesis Total
Only three of our patients had ankle instability pre­ operatively.
By both physical examination and instru­ mented ligament testing at follow-up, none of our patients had evidence of chronic ankle instability.
Thus, we agree with Bassett and Speef that lateral ligamentous instability appears not to be a prerequi­ site for tears of the peroneus brevis and that damage to the SPR causing subclinical subluxation may occur with the uncomplicated ankle sprain or with other unrecognized injuries.
Other considerations with re­ gard to the pathophysiology must include the pres­ ence of a shallow fibular groove, hindfoot valgus, and/or laterally lying tendons as predisposing factors for peroneal tendon subluxation with minimal injury.19 The question arises whether there is an underlying, intrinsic degeneration caused by an avascular zone of the tendon, as seen elsewhere in the hindfoot and ankle region, e.g., the tibialis posterior tendon?
Pero­ neal tendon tears are typical, in this series as well as in other reports, for the complete deficiency of interstitial fibrous tissue.
Meyer13 noted that even in patients incapacitated for a considerable period, no healing had occurred.
Meyer13 also noted a complete ab­ sence of gross reparative processes including "ab­ sence of evidence of hemorrhage or of coagulum of any kind," which suggested "the necessary men­ struum for reparative processes is absent" in peroneal tendons.
However, recent studies have shown vascu­ lar proliferation that verifies an adequate blood supply for healing.14,20,23 Microvascular studies fail to show a zone of hypovascularity corresponding to the site of peroneus brevis tears as has been shown for other attritional tendon tears?,16,24 Several studies14,20,23 document that adequate vascularity does exist and that there are no data to support an hypothesis that weakening and degeneration occur as a result of the loss of viable, vascularized tendon tissue.

Patient Data > PERONEUS BREVIS TENDON TEARS 277
Subluxation of the tendons over the sharp edge of the posterior fibula and/or its fibrocartilage clearly ap­ pears to be the usual, direct mechanism of peroneus brevis tendon tears in our patients.
However, the un­ derlying cause of the subluxation itself appears to be neither uniform to all cases nor easily discerned in many cases.
In the 12 of 20 patients in this study who did not have clinically evident subluxation of the ten­ dons preoperatively, we were unable to ascertain with confidence the ultimate source of the subluxation it­ self.

Patient Data > PERONEUS BREVIS TENDON TEARS 277
Diagnosis

Patient Data > PERONEUS BREVIS TENDON TEARS 277
The incidence of peroneus brevis tears in the gen­ eral public is unknown.
Two separate cadaveric stud­ ies by Sobel et al.21,23 suggested the very different incidences of 11.3% and 37% in elderly patients.
The answer is almost certainly in between the high num­ bers suggested by cadaver studies and the small numbers reported clinically.

Patient Data > PERONEUS BREVIS TENDON TEARS 277
Clinical swelling over the peroneal tendons was present in 90% of our patients.
This is the most con­ sistent clinical finding in patients with peroneal ten-

Patient Data > Treatment
Our opinion is that treatment for peroneus brevis tear is largely surgical.
Previous reports of peroneus brevis tears, though small in number, also recom­ mended surgical treatment.

Patient Data > Treatment
1,11,14,20 Our experience is that chronic subluxation is almost always present.
Surgery must primarily address this lesion in order to prevent further attrition of the tendon.
The recognition of subluxation as the "final common pathway" to de­ veloping the painful lesion of peroneal tendon tears is one of the fundamental findings of this study.
Tendon debridement/repair and tubularization has been advocated by several authors.
2,11,19,20 If suffi­ cient tendon is healthy and viable, repair is indicated.
In our series, this option was elected if 50% or more of the transverse or cross-sectional area of the tendon was viable and remained after debridement (grade 1).12 If less than 50% of the tendon (grade 2) was viable after debridement, we performed a complete resection of the damaged segment and proximal and distal tenodeses to the peroneus longus.
Peroneal tenodesis has been recommended for peroneus lon­ gus ruptures'" but has been described in only one patient with a peroneus brevis tear.!"
Our results dem­ onstrate that the tenodesis functions satisfactorily.
No patient had a unilateral foot deformity at follow-up, dons tears.
Tenderness over the tendons and pain with resisted eversion were also common findings.
Tenderness and pain with resisted eversion may also be seen in peroneal tendonitis in the absence of ten­ don tears, but swelling is almost always a hallmark of the more florid synovitis engendered by a torn tendon.

Patient Data > Treatment
Chronic peroneal tendinitis can be slow to resolve, and, at times, resistant to therapy, but is usually re­ solved with conservative therapy and is usually re­ solved in less time than the average 14-month delay until diagnosis experienced by this series of patients.

Patient Data > Treatment
The diagnosis may be aided by imaging studies, namely magnetic resonance imaging (MRI).
However, there are significant pitfalls in the use of MRI to make the diagnosis because criteria for peroneal tendon tears are not well established?
Despite familiarity with this diagnosis by our radiologists, we still noted a 27% false-negative rate in the MRI studies.4,9,18 In patients with swelling in the peroneal sheath and tenderness posterior to the lateral malleolus, a high index of sus­ picion for peroneus brevis tears should arise.
Appro­ priate therapeutic measures should not depend en­ tirely upon the imaging reports but must take in to account the clinical findings, perhaps despite the find­ ings of the MRI in some cases, at least until better diagnostic criteria have been established.

Patient Data > Treatment

19, No. 5/May 1998

Patient Data > Treatment
and all had active eversion of the foot.
Subjective and objective results were not substantially different be­ tween the tenodesis group and the tendon repair group.

Patient Data > Treatment
We proposed a new classification system to guide surgical decision-making.
Our system is based on the transverse width (cross-sectional area) of viable ten­ don that remains after debridement of the damaged portion of the tendon.
This presumes that the retained portion of the tendon has no longitudinal tears.

Patient Data > Treatment
The two grades reflect the extent of tendon destruc­ tion.
Our recommendation is that grade 1 lesions be treated with tendon repair and grade 2 lesions be treated with segmental resection and tenodesis.
We believe that when greater than 50% of the cross­ sectional area of the tendon is destroyed, too little tendon remains to be functional.
This could result in excessively high stress in the remaining tendon and lead to its eventual complete rupture.F While the length of the tear may be important at times, it is more important to recognize the width (cross-sectional area) of tendon damage If the tendon has a very long tear that is localized to one margin of the tendon, this has much better prospect for preser­ vation of the tendon than multiple, short tears located in the middle of the tendon that compromise more of the cross-sectional area of the tendon.
At the time of surgery, we found quite a great variation in the length of the tendon tear but could find no way to apply that information to practical treatment decision-making.

Patient Data > Treatment
Our classification system allows separating tears by degree of involvement in a way that guides surgical decisions for method of reconstruction.

Patient Data > Treatment
The overall surgical results were encouraging.
No patient required any further surgery.
All patients ex­ cept one who were employed preinjury returned to work, although three changed to more sedentary-type positions.
Questions remain regarding the underlying cause of the subtle or overt subluxation of the pero­ neal tendons that leads to tears of the peroneus brevis tendon.
Greater awareness of this diagnosis and ap­ propriate treatment should yield larger numbers of cases and further experience in the orthopaedic com­ munity in the future.

Patient Data > Treatment > CONCLUSIONS
1. Peroneus brevis tears are frequently overlooked or misdiagnosed yet appear to be more common that previously reported.

Patient Data > Treatment > CONCLUSIONS
2. Swelling along the peroneal sheath is the most reliable diagnostic sign of peroneus brevis tendon tear.

Patient Data > Treatment > CONCLUSIONS > PERONEUS BREVIS TENDON TEARS 279 > 28. Thompson, F
4. Treatment of peroneus brevis tears is primarily surgical.
Debridement and tendon repair are recom­ mended for less extensive damage (grade 1); resec­ tion and tenodesis to the peroneus longus for the more severe tears (grade 2).
Both methods must be augmented by a peroneal tendon stabilization proce­ dure that addresses the underlying subluxation of the tendons.

Patient Data > Treatment > CONCLUSIONS > PERONEUS BREVIS TENDON TEARS 279 > 28. Thompson, F
5. Return to maximum function after surgery is pro­ longed, but good to excellent results can be expected.
